rev.diff:
Line 13: Line 13:
Data file compression is employed in order to reduce bandwidth, file transfer time, and/or storage requirements. A digital recording (such as a [[CD]]) encoded to the Monkey's Audio format can be decompressed into an identical copy of the original audio data. As with the [[FLAC]] and [[Apple Lossless]] format, files encoded to Monkey's Audio are typically reduced to about half of the original size,<ref>[http://www.monkeysaudio.com/comparison.html Monkey's Audio official comparison]</ref> with data transfer rates and bandwidth requirements being reduced accordingly.
Data file compression is employed in order to reduce bandwidth, file transfer time, and/or storage requirements. A digital recording (such as a [[CD]]) encoded to the Monkey's Audio format can be decompressed into an identical copy of the original audio data. As with the [[FLAC]] and [[Apple Lossless]] format, files encoded to Monkey's Audio are typically reduced to about half of the original size,<ref>[http://www.monkeysaudio.com/comparison.html Monkey's Audio official comparison]</ref> with data transfer rates and bandwidth requirements being reduced accordingly.
â
Monkey's Audio's advantages are slightly superior compression rates compared to [[FLAC]] and [[WavPack]],<ref>http://flake-enc.sourceforge.net/benchmarks.html</ref><ref>http://web.inter.nl.net/users/hvdh/lossless/All.htm</ref><ref>http://members.home.nl/w.speek/comparison.htm</ref> as well [[multithreading]]/multicore support.<ref name=ver>http://www.monkeysaudio.com/versionhistory.html</ref> Monkey's Audio main drawbacks are the fact that it employs a symmetric algorithm, meaning the decoding takes comparable resources to encoding, which makes it unsuitable for all but the fastest portable players (via [[Rockbox]] firmware),<ref name=rockbox>http://www.rockbox.org/wiki/SoundCodecMonkeysAudio</ref> and that it has limited support on software platforms other than Windows; on other platforms only decoding is officially supported by third-party programs. Although the original source code is freely available, the license is not considered to be an [[open source]] one.<ref name='gentoo'/><ref name=ubuntu/> A [[GPL]] version of the decoder has been independently written and included in [[ffmpeg]].<ref name=ubuntu/><ref name=ffmpeg>http://ffmpeg.org/releases/ffmpeg-0.5.changelog</ref>
+
Monkey's Audio's advantages are slightly superior compression rates compared to [[FLAC]] and [[WavPack]],<ref>http://flake-enc.sourceforge.net/benchmarks.html</ref><ref>http://web.inter.nl.net/users/hvdh/lossless/All.htm</ref><ref>http://members.home.nl/w.speek/comparison.htm</ref> as well [[multithreading]]/multicore support.<ref name=ver>http://www.monkeysaudio.com/versionhistory.html</ref> Monkey's Audio main drawbacks are the fact that it employs a symmetric algorithm, meaning the decoding takes comparable resources to encoding, which makes it unsuitable for all but the fastest portable players (via [[Rockbox]] firmware),<ref name=rockbox>http://www.rockbox.org/wiki/SoundCodecMonkeysAudio</ref> and that it has limited support on software platforms other than Windows; on other platforms only decoding is officially supported by third-party programs. Although the original [[source code]] is freely available, the license is not considered to be an [[open source]] one.<ref name='gentoo'/><ref name=ubuntu/> A [[GPL]] version of the decoder has been independently written and included in [[ffmpeg]].<ref name=ubuntu/><ref name=ffmpeg>http://ffmpeg.org/releases/ffmpeg-0.5.changelog</ref>
Monkey's Audio files use the [[filename extension]] <tt>.ape</tt> for audio, and <tt>.apl</tt> for track metadata.
Monkey's Audio files use the [[filename extension]] <tt>.ape</tt> for audio, and <tt>.apl</tt> for track metadata.
